ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned engineering problem solving skills by working on problems relating to system balances (mass, chemical) in relation to common engineering systems.

As a high school student, I am incredibly grateful for this course, as It not only introduced me to the college environment of classes, coursework, and teaching patterns but also provided an in-depth exploration of the subject I aspire to pursue in the future. Throughout the course, I had the opportunity to learn numerous concepts, including steady state systems, thermodynamics, entropy, enthalpy, and many more. This enriching experience has left a profound impact on me.

Moreover, the course went beyond the syllabus and offered valuable insights into college life. The emphasis on collaboration and teamwork was a refreshing change for me, as it was something I had been missing in my previous summer school experiences. This aspect of the course not only enhanced my learning but also allowed me to develop essential skills for my future academic and professional endeavors.
I developed skills to analyze any given situation. Ranging from tanks and turbines to rooms with any source.
Increased my intuition about systems and how we can define relationships of physical phenomena to each other,
Flexibility and literacy in concepts of chemical engineering, including dimensional analysis and intuitive applications of chemistry.
I learned about dimensionless variables and I learned how to solve a variety of engineering problems!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is good at teaching you how to improvise as there are many ways to solve the problems and the environment is very collaborative.

for me, the course had it strength in its curriculum, and its classes. The curriculum was put together for a great introduction into mathematical modelling and chemical engineering, without scarring me like the high school textbooks. The classes were well engaging and collaborative for students to receive enough assistance and help from teachers and their peers. The teaching style of the proffesor was great for me to adapt to and understand concepts quickly. Another strength, which I personally appreciate, was the office hours and additional assistance offered by the professor, as it did never resulted in a pause or frustration while learning in the last 4 weeks.

The course finds itself in a tough place as an intro course because you do need some extra background beyond the lectures for things to make sense, but the depth of the course is also limited because of the timescale if you do have the background. Overall, a fun course and Loewenberg is great.

The course is delightfully challenging and the diet of material (Psets/Tests/Classwork ratio) is wonderful, stimulating without being stressful. The course could benefit from a slower, more granular approach to the problems it poses.

I liked the format of short lectures in combination with group work! Also, the problem sets were a manageable about of work and they were instructive. In general, I think its hard to have active participation in class and during group work over zoom, but if there was a way to encourage this more, the class would probably more engaging for everyone.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I think this course is being replaced soon, but if you are at all interested in chemical engineering or just problem solving I recommend it!
definitely, it serves as a great introduction into the STEM field and the teaching and assistance by the professor make it a great experience.
Yes, It is a good class to be gain skills and tools to analyze everyday situations.
Take it! It isn't too difficult but builds some interesting intuition. The course doesn't have that much depth but it is a summer course and introductory, so that's to be expected.
Yes, it was achievable for someone unfamiliar with the material and I can imagine it would be very engaging and even fun for someone better acquainted.

Yes! This is a great course, especially if you take it with Prof. Loewenberg!! He is a gem, and he makes the material engaging and approachable. The workload is super manageable, and you'll come out of the course understanding how a variety of different types of mechanical problems can be approached.

comments: Agree

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: It will assist me in my upcoming classes and hopefully my future jobs at some point.
Buckingham Pi provides some really interesting intuition on defining the relationships between characteristics of a system that will continue to be helpful in engineering and science.
Delightful course. Newfound confidence in flexibility of technique during problem solving broadly speaking
The class taught me in general how to approach problems and how to break complex problems into simpler parts. This skill will be useful in most all of my future academic pursuits.
